entry.title: Notes on Deep Generative Model
entry.content:
In this note, I cover some basic aspects of autoregressive generative models, where the learning of data distributions is done in a supervised fashion under the modeling assumption that there exists an ordering of inputs such that the conditional distribution of an input can be compactly represented/parameterized as a function of all inputs that come before it in the ordering. Notable autoregressive architectures include PixelCNN, Transformer, etc.

Generative Model

In generative modeling, we assume that our data set DDD is a set of samples from some probability distribution pdatap_{data}pdata​, and the goal is to be able to approximate such a probability distribution given our access to DDD. One way of doing so is via parametric models. That is, we have a family of probability distributions {pθ:θ∈Θ}\{p_{\mathbf{\theta}}: \mathbf{\theta} \in \Theta \}{pθ​:θ∈Θ} parameterized by some (possibly high dimensional vector) θ\mathbf{\theta}θ, and our goal is to learn a parameter θ∗\mathbf{\theta^*}θ∗ such that

θ∗=arg⁡min⁡θ∈Θd(pθ,pdata), \mathbf{\theta^*} = \arg\min_{\mathbf{\theta} \in \Theta} d(p_\theta, p_{data}),θ∗=argθ∈Θmin​d(pθ​,pdata​),

where d(⋅,⋅)d(\cdot, \cdot)d(⋅,⋅) is some notion of distance between distributions, for e.g. KL divergence. Note that we do not know what pdatap_{data}pdata​ is (that’s why we would like to approximate it), but we have information on pdatap_{data}pdata​ via our training data DDD.

Autoregressive Models

Given a probability distribution ppp and a sample x=(x1,…,xn)\mathbf{x} = (x_1,\dots,x_n)x=(x1​,…,xn​), we can factorize the density as

p(x)=∏i=1np(xi∣x<i),p(\mathbf{x}) = \prod_{i=1}^n p(x_i | \mathbf{x}_{<i}),p(x)=i=1∏n​p(xi​∣x<i​),

where x_<i=(x1,…,xi−1)\mathbf{x}\_{<i} = (x_1,\dots,x_{i-1})x_<i=(x1​,…,xi−1​). Here, we can see where the term autoregressive comes from: given an ordering x1,…,xnx_1,\dots,x_nx1​,…,xn​, the distribution of the xix_ixi​ is dependent on the distribution of all the random variables that come before it: x1,…,xi−1x_1, \dots, x_{i-1}x1​,…,xi−1​.

Now, for a moment, assume that each xix_ixi​ is a Bernouilli random variable, then in order to specify p(x)p(\mathbf{x})p(x), we would need 1=201=2^01=20 parameter for p(x1)p(x_1)p(x1​), 212^121 parameters for p(x2∣x1)p(x_2 \mid x_1)p(x2​∣x1​), 2i−12^{i-1}2i−1 parameters for p(xi∣x_<i)p(x_i \mid \mathbf{x}\_{<i})p(xi​∣x_<i), giving a total of

1+2+⋯+2n−1=2n−11 + 2 + \dots + 2^{n-1} = 2^n -11+2+⋯+2n−1=2n−1

parameters. This means that the space complexity is exponential in the dimension of the input, rendering the tabular approach unemployable.

Thus, in an autoregressive generative model, one assumes that

pθi(xi∣x<i)=p1(fi(x1,…,xi−1)),p_{\theta_i} (x_i | \mathbf{x}_{<i}) = p_1(f_i(x_1,\dots,x_{i-1})),pθi​​(xi​∣x<i​)=p1​(fi​(x1​,…,xi−1​)),

where the set of parameters θi\theta_iθi​ specifies the function fif_ifi​, which supplies the necessary parameters for the one-dimensional probability distributrion p1p_1p1​. For example:

  1. If xi∈Rx_i \in \mathbb Rxi​∈R is a continuous distribution, p1p_1p1​ could be a normal distribution with mean and variance specified by fif_ifi​.
  2. If xi∈{0,1}x_i \in \{0,1\}xi​∈{0,1} is a binary random variable, then p1p_1p1​ could be Bernouilli with mean given by fif_ifi​.
  3. If xix_ixi​ is categorical, then p1p_1p1​ could be softmax with logits given by fif_ifi​.

Thus, the total number of parameters is ∑i=1n∣θi∣\sum_{i=1}^n |\theta_i|∑i=1n​∣θi​∣.

Fully-visible sigmoid belief network (FVSBN)

Suppose that xi∈{0,1}x_i \in \{0,1\}xi​∈{0,1} for 1≤i≤n1 \leq i \leq n1≤i≤n. Then, we have that p1p_1p1​ is a Bernouilli distribution, and so fif_ifi​ as the parameter of a Bernouilli must have domain [0,1][0,1][0,1]. Thus, in the simplest case, we can just let it be the sigmoid of the linear combination of all previous random variables:

p(xi∣x<i)=fi(x1,…,xi−1)=σ(α0(i)+∑j=1i−1αj(i)xj,) p(x_i|\mathbf{x}_{<i}) = f_i(x_1,\dots,x_{i-1}) = \sigma\left( \alpha_0^{(i)} + \sum_{j=1}^{i-1} \alpha_j^{(i)} x_{j}, \right) p(xi​∣x<i​)=fi​(x1​,…,xi−1​)=σ(α0(i)​+j=1∑i−1​αj(i)​xj​,) so here the set of parameter is θi={αj(i):0≤j≤i−1}\theta_i = \{ \alpha^{(i)}_j : 0 \leq j \leq i-1 \}θi​={αj(i)​:0≤j≤i−1}. As such, the total number of parameters is ∑i=1n∣θi∣=∑i=1ni=O(n2)\sum_{i=1}^n |\theta_i| = \sum_{i=1}^n i = O(n^2)∑i=1n​∣θi​∣=∑i=1n​i=O(n2). We have now reduced the number of parameters from exponential to polynomial in input dimension.

Neural autoregressive density estimation (NADE)

Clearly, a natural way to make the FVSBN model more complex is to use a more complex architecture to specify the function fif_ifi​. For example, we can use a one layer neural network instead of the logistic model to specify fif_ifi​:

Since the model is more expressive, there are also more parameters. The total number is ∑i=1n(d(i+1)+1)=O(n2d)\sum_{i=1}^n (d(i+1) + 1) = O(n^2d)∑i=1n​(d(i+1)+1)=O(n2d). This is still polynomial in the input dimension and linear in the depth of the hidden layer.

In NADE, however, parameters are shared in the hidden layer. That is, instead of having a separate matrix AiA_iAi​ and bias vector cic_ici​ to compute each hih_ihi​, we assume universal shared matrix W∈Rd×nW \in \R^{d \times n}W∈Rd×n and c∈Rdc \in \R^dc∈Rd. Then, in order to compute hih_ihi​, we specify Ai=W:,<i∈Rd×(i−1)A_i = W_{:, <i} \in \R^{d \times (i-1)}Ai​=W:,<i​∈Rd×(i−1), which is the matrix formed by the first (i−1)(i-1)(i−1) columns of WWW. The total number of parameters is now (n+1)d+∑i=1n(d+1)=O(nd)(n+1)d + \sum_{i=1}^n (d+1) = O(nd)(n+1)d+∑i=1n​(d+1)=O(nd), which is linear in the input dimension.

More general input types

The FVSBN and NADE models can be easily extended to other input types such as categorical or continuous, i.e. for example when p1p_1p1​ as discussed above is given by softmax or normal distribution.

For categorical inputs xix_ixi​ with kkk values, we simply let αi∈Rd×k\alpha_i \in \R^{d \times k}αi​∈Rd×k, bi∈Rkb_i \in \R^kbi​∈Rk, and σ\sigmaσ is now the softmax function, where

σ(z)=σ((z1,…,zk))=(exp⁡(a1)∑iexp⁡(ai),…,exp⁡(ak)∑iexp⁡(ai)).\sigma(\mathbf{z}) = \sigma((z_1,\dots,z_k)) = \left( \frac{\exp(a_1)}{\sum_i \exp(a_i)}, \dots, \frac{\exp(a_k)}{\sum_i \exp(a_i)} \right).σ(z)=σ((z1​,…,zk​))=(∑i​exp(ai​)exp(a1​)​,…,∑i​exp(ai​)exp(ak​)​).

For continuous inputs xix_ixi​ and p1p_1p1​ given by a normal distribution, we can have σ\sigmaσ outputs a two dimensional vector (μi,σi)(\mu_i, \sigma_i)(μi​,σi​), so that p(xi∣x<i)∼N(μi,σi2)p(x_i|\mathbf{x}_{<i}) \sim N(\mu_i, \sigma_i^2)p(xi​∣x<i​)∼N(μi​,σi2​). This can also be generalized to a uniform mixture of KKK Gaussians, which gives us the RNADE model.

Autoencoders and MADE for Fast Training

Comparison: Autoregressive models v.s. autoencoders

The autoregressive FVSBN and NADE models seem very similar to an autoencoder. For example, for the NADE, we can think of h=(h1,…,hn)=e(x)h = (h_1,\dots, h_n) = e(\mathbf{x})h=(h1​,…,hn​)=e(x) as the encoded version of x\mathbf{x}x. In the decoding phase, we get x^i=σ(αiThi+bi)=d(h)i=d(e(x))i\hat x_i = \sigma(\alpha_i^T h_i + b_i) = d(h)_i = d(e(\mathbf{x}))_ix^i​=σ(αiT​hi​+bi​)=d(h)i​=d(e(x))i​ as the decoded version. For an autoencoder, we aim to have d(e(x))≈xd(e(\mathbf{x})) \approx \mathbf{x}d(e(x))≈x, and so for binary xix_ixi​’s, the logistic loss is a suitable minimization objective ∑x∈D∑i−xilog⁡x^i−(1−xi)log⁡(1−x^i). \sum_{\mathbf{x} \in D} \sum_i - x_i \log \hat x_i - (1-x_i) \log(1-\hat x_i).x∈D∑​i∑​−xi​logx^i​−(1−xi​)log(1−x^i​).

On the other hand, our objective for generative models like NADE as mentioned in the first section is to find optimal parameter θ∗\theta^*θ∗ that minimizes d(pθ,pdata),d(p_\theta, p_{data}),d(pθ​,pdata​), where ddd is some notion of distance between probability distributions. In the case where ddd is the KL divergence

d(pθ,pdata)=Ex∼pdata[log⁡pdata(x)−log⁡pθ(x)],d(p_\theta, p_{data}) = \mathbb E_{\mathbf{x} \sim p_{data}} [\log p_{data}(x) - \log p_\theta(x)],d(pθ​,pdata​)=Ex∼pdata​​[logpdata​(x)−logpθ​(x)],

minimizing the distance is equivalent to maximizing the log-likelihood

Ex∼pdata[log⁡pθ(x)].\mathbb E_{\mathbf{x} \sim p_{data}} [\log p_\theta(\mathbf{x})].Ex∼pdata​​[logpθ​(x)]. Notice now that since

pθ(x)=∏i=1np(xi∣x<i)=∏i=1nBern(x^i),p_\theta(\mathbf{x}) = \prod_{i=1}^n p(x_i|\mathbf x_{<i}) = \prod_{i=1}^n \mathrm{Bern}(\hat x_i),pθ​(x)=i=1∏n​p(xi​∣x<i​)=i=1∏n​Bern(x^i​),

we get that log⁡pθ(x)=∑ixilog⁡x^i+(1−xi)log⁡(1−x^i). \log p_\theta(\mathbf x) = \sum_i x_i \log \hat x_i + (1-x_i) \log (1- \hat x_i).logpθ​(x)=i∑​xi​logx^i​+(1−xi​)log(1−x^i​).

So, the objective of the generative model to minimize the KL divergence is also maximizing the log-likelihood, which is equivalent to minimize the logistic loss. That is, it looks exactly like the objective of the autoencoder.

However, one distinction between an autoregressive model like NADE and an autoencoder is the probabilistic semantics: in autoregressive models, we have an ordering on the random variables xix_ixi​, and the conditional probability of x^i\hat x_ix^i​ can only depend on x<i\mathbf{x}_{<i}x<i​. On the other hand, there is no such constraint on a vanilla autoencoder.

MADE for fast training

Notice that due to the autoregressive behavior, in order to compute the probability density at an input point x∈Rn\mathbf{x} \in \R^nx∈Rn, due to the different network used to compute p(xi∣x<i)p(x_i|\mathbf{x}_{<i})p(xi​∣x<i​), we need nnn passes in order to compute x^=p(x)=∏i=1np(xi∣x<i)\hat{\mathbf x} = p(\mathbf{x}) = \prod_{i=1}^n p(x_i|\mathbf{x}_{<i})x^=p(x)=∏i=1n​p(xi​∣x<i​). On the other hand, in an autoencoder, we only need a single forward pass in order to compute x^\hat{\mathbf x}x^. The question is how one can make an autoencoder into an autoregressive model, where the probabilistic structure is respected. This is where the Masked Autoencoder for Distribution Estimation (MADE) comes in.

The idea is to prohibit paths that in an autoencoder that does not respect the conditional probability structure. For simplicity, suppose n=3n=3n=3 and our ordering is again x1,x2,x3x_1, x_2, x_3x1​,x2​,x3​. Clearly, the conditional probability structure mandates that p(x1)p(x_1)p(x1​) does not depend on the any other inputs while p(x2)p(x_2)p(x2​) can only be dependent on x1x_1x1​, and p(x3)p(x_3)p(x3​) can only depend on x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​. This means that paths from x1x_1x1​ can reach x^2\hat x_2x^2​ or x^3\hat x_3x^3​ but not x^1\hat x_1x^1​; paths from x2x_2x2​ can reach x^3\hat x_3x^3​ but not x^1\hat x_1x^1​ or x^2\hat x_2x^2​, and there is no path from x3x_3x3​ that is allowed to reach the output layer.

In order to enforce these rules, we first label the input and output neurons with the given ordering. Then, for each unit in the hidden layer, we label it by a random integer i∈{1,…,n−1}i \in \{1,\dots, n-1\}i∈{1,…,n−1}. Any unit with label iii in the hidden layers can only connect to neurons in previous layers that are labeled {1,…,i}\{1,\dots, i\}{1,…,i}. Finally, any unit in the output layer with label iii can only connect to neurons in the previous layer that are labeled {1,…,i−1}\{1,\dots, i-1\}{1,…,i−1}. These rules immediately enforce that x^i\hat x_ix^i​ can only depend on x<i\mathbf{x}_{<i}x<i​. In terms of implementation, we can use masking matrices to do this.

Final Thoughts on Autoregressive Models

  1. We have analytical form of p(x)=∏i=1np(xi∣x<i)p(\mathbf x) = \prod_{i=1}^n p(x_i | \mathbf{x}_{<i})p(x)=∏i=1n​p(xi​∣x<i​). This means that the log-likelihood can be evaluated easily, especially via using MADE for parallel computing. Thus, training can be done efficiently.
  2. Sequential sampling can be done easily, BUT is not efficient because it is sequential.
  3. These models require an ordering, and different orderings can lead to different result (because we assume a compact representation for parameterization).
  4. There is no natural way to get features via unsupervised learning.
entry.summary: In this note, I cover some basic aspects of autoregressive generative models, where the learning of data distributions is done in a supervised fashion under the modeling assumption that there exists an ordering of inputs such that the conditional distribution of an input can be compactly represented/parameterized as a function of all inputs that come before it in the ordering. Notable autoregressive architectures include PixelCNN, Transformer, etc.

entry.title: A Bayesian View of Neural Networks

link.title: A Bayesian View of Neural Networks

entry.title: A Bayesian View of Neural Networks

link.title: A Bayesian View of Neural Networks

entry.content:
In the last part, we went over an introduction to the Bayesian approach in machine learning, where we think of a neural network model from a weight-space point of view. In this post, I will go over an alternative approach, whereby we apply Bayesian inference directly in the function space. That is, instead of thinking of the model as specifying the probability distribution over the weights in a neural network, we are thinking of it as specifying a probability distribution over functions whose domain is the space of inputs of the network, and the codomain as the space of its outputs.

Stochastic processes

A stochastic process is a collection of random variables {Xt}t∈T\{X_t\}_{t \in T}{Xt​}t∈T​ that are indexed by some set TTT. A stochastic process is a Gaussian process if for every finite collection of indices (t1,…,tn)(t_1,\dots,t_n)(t1​,…,tn​), we have that (Xt1,…,Xtn)(X_{t_1},\dots, X_{t_n})(Xt1​​,…,Xtn​​) is a multivariate Gaussian random variable.

Just like Gaussian random variables, a Gaussian process can be completely characterized by its mean and covariance functions:

m(t)=E[Xt]k(t,t′)=E[(Xt−m(t))(Xt′−m(t′))T]\begin{aligned} m(t) &= \mathbb E[X_t] \\ k(t,t') &= \mathbb E[(X_t - m(t))(X_{t'} - m(t'))^T] \end{aligned}m(t)k(t,t′)​=E[Xt​]=E[(Xt​−m(t))(Xt′​−m(t′))T]​

Usually, the index set is denoted as TTT for its interpretation as time. For example, the well-known Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process is a Gaussian process, and Brownian motion is a stochastic process that is the integral of a white noise generalized Gaussian process. These are beyond the scope of this blog post, but it could be of interest to some readers.

Example: Gaussian process prior over functions

The index set does not need to be time or even one-dimensional, as we shall see in the case of neural network. As an example, consider the following simple kernel-based regression architecture:

In particular, our architecture specifies for inputs x∈Rdx \in \mathbb R^dx∈Rd, the output is f(x)=wTϕ(x)f(\mathbf x) = \mathbf w^T \phi(\mathbf x)f(x)=wTϕ(x), where w∼N(0,Σn)\mathbf{w} \sim \mathcal N(0, \Sigma_n)w∼N(0,Σn​). Here, we can view {f(x)}x∈Rd\{f(\mathbf x)\}_{\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb R^d}{f(x)}x∈Rd​ as a Gaussian process, where the index set is Rd\mathbb R^dRd (when the index set is multidimensional, i.e. when d>1d>1d>1, this is also commonly known as a Gaussian random field). This process has the following mean and covariance functions:

m(x)=E[wTϕ(x)]=E[wT]ϕ(x)=0k(x,x′)=E[ϕ(x)TwwTϕ(x)]=ϕ(x)TΣnϕ(x′)\begin{aligned} m(\mathbf{x}) &= \mathbb E[\mathbf{w}^T \phi(\mathbf{x})] = \mathbb E[\mathbf{w}^T] \phi(\mathbf{x}) = 0 \\ k(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x'}) &= \mathbb E[\phi(\mathbf{x})^T \mathbf{w w}^T \phi(\mathbf x)] = \phi(\mathbf{x})^T \Sigma_n \phi(\mathbf{x'}) \end{aligned}m(x)k(x,x′)​=E[wTϕ(x)]=E[wT]ϕ(x)=0=E[ϕ(x)TwwTϕ(x)]=ϕ(x)TΣn​ϕ(x′)​

Thus, from this point of view, we have that the architecture specifies a Gaussian process prior over our function space:

f(⋅)∼GP(0,k(⋅,⋅)) f(\cdot) \sim \mathcal{GP}(0, k(\cdot, \cdot)) f(⋅)∼GP(0,k(⋅,⋅))

Bayesian inference with Gaussian processes

Just as before, we are interested in updating our belief once we have gathered more observations. That is, we want to compute the posterior distribution over functions given the training data {(xi,fi):1≤i≤n}\{(\mathbf{x}_i, f_i): 1 \leq i \leq n \}{(xi​,fi​):1≤i≤n}. For now, assume that our observations are noise-free. Suppose further that we want to obtain outputs for mmm test points {(xi∗,f∗):1≤i≤m}\{(x_i^*, f^*): 1 \leq i \leq m\}{(xi∗​,f∗):1≤i≤m}.

Let X=(x1,…,xn)X = (x_1,\dots,x_n)X=(x1​,…,xn​),, ,X∗=(x1∗,…,xm∗)X^* = (x_1^*,\dots, x_m^*)X∗=(x1∗​,…,xm∗​), f=(f1,…,fn)\mathbf{f} = (f_1,\dots, f_n)f=(f1​,…,fn​), and f∗=(f1∗,…,fm∗)\mathbf{f^*} = (f_1^*,\dots, f_m^*)f∗=(f1∗​,…,fm∗​). Because f(⋅)∼GP(0,k(⋅,⋅))f(\cdot) \sim \mathcal{GP}(0, k(\cdot, \cdot))f(⋅)∼GP(0,k(⋅,⋅)), we have that the joint distribution of these data points are

[ff∗]∼N(0,[K(X,X)K(X,X∗)K(X∗,X)K(X∗,X∗)]), \left[\begin{matrix} \mathbf{f} \\ \mathbf{f^*} \end{matrix}\right]\sim \mathcal{N} \left(0, \left[ \begin{matrix} K(X,X) & K(X,X^*) \\ K(X^*, X) & K(X^*,X^*) \end{matrix}\right] \right),[ff∗​]∼N(0,[K(X,X)K(X∗,X)​K(X,X∗)K(X∗,X∗)​]),

where K(A,B)=[k(a,b)]a∈A,b∈BK(A,B)= [k(a,b)]_{a \in A, b \in B}K(A,B)=[k(a,b)]a∈A,b∈B​ is an ∣A∣×∣B∣\left|A \right| \times \left|B \right|∣A∣×∣B∣ matrix.

To compute the posterior, we thus simply use the rule for conditioning Gaussian to obtain

f∗∣X∗,X,f∼N(μ∗,k∗),\mathbf{f^*} \mid X^*, X, \mathbf{f} \sim \mathcal N(\mu^*,k^*),f∗∣X∗,X,f∼N(μ∗,k∗),

where

μ∗=K(X∗,X)K(X,X)−1fk∗=K(X∗,X∗)−K(X∗,X)K(X,X)−1K(X,X∗).\begin{aligned} \mu^* &= K(X^*,X) K(X,X)^{-1} \mathbf{f} \\ k^* &= K(X^*,X^*) - K(X^*,X)K(X,X)^{-1} K(X,X^*) \end{aligned}.μ∗k∗​=K(X∗,X)K(X,X)−1f=K(X∗,X∗)−K(X∗,X)K(X,X)−1K(X,X∗)​.

In other words, our posterior is again a Gaussian process, with mean and covariance function given by specifying the set X∗X^*X∗ in the above formulas for μ∗\mu^*μ∗ and k∗k^*k∗.

Simulated example

Note that for the above example of the simple kernel-based neural network, for a set X={x1,…,xn}X = \{\mathbf{x_1},\dots,\mathbf{x_n}\}X={x1​,…,xn​} of nnn different inputs, if n>dn>dn>d, where ddd is the dimension of the input, then although f(x1),…,f(xn)f(\mathbf{x_1}),\dots, f(\mathbf{x_n})f(x1​),…,f(xn​) is still distributed as a multivariate Gaussian, its covariance matrix is singular, and conditioning on knowing any f(xi1),…,f(xid)f(\mathbf{x_{i_1}}), \dots, f(\mathbf{x_{i_d}})f(xi1​​),…,f(xid​​), we know what f(⋅)f(\cdot)f(⋅) is. This means that one-dimensional problems are boring because knowing value of 1 non-degenerate point results in knowing the function. (only true in the case where our observations are not noisy).

As such, let us look at a more interesting example (not arising from kernel-based neural network), where the covariance function is given by:

k(x,x′)=exp⁡(−12∥x−x′∥2).k(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x'}) = \exp\left( - \frac{1}{2}\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x'} \|^2 \right).k(x,x′)=exp(−21​∥x−x′∥2).

Here is a plot showing a simulation when x∈R\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb Rx∈R and the Gaussian process is defined with the above exponential decay kernel. On the left, we have sample of functions drawn from the GP prior, while on the right, we have the posterior given the five data points (blue dots). The shaded area corresponds to 2 standard deviations away from the mean of the distribution.

As opposed to the prior where the standard deviation is the same across all input points, after observing the training data, we updated our belief to have much more confidence in the area of inputs between any two observed data points. In this particular case, because the observation is noise-free, there is no uncertainty regarding the outputs at the input points where we have training data. Furthermore, as we use the exponential prior k(x,x′)=exp⁡(−12∥x−x′∥2).k(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x'}) = \exp\left( - \frac{1}{2}\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x'} \|^2 \right).k(x,x′)=exp(−21​∥x−x′∥2)., points that are closed together have high covariance, and so the functions drawn are smooth. As a result for the posterior, we can see that between any two given data points with high slope change (for e.g. the second and third one), we have more confidence in the prediction as the variance is smaller, as is evidenced from the smaller width of the shaded area.

General neural network

In general, a neural network may not be a Gaussian process, even for a single layer one with weights distributed as independent Gaussian variables:

Although W0x+b0W^0x +b^0W0x+b0 is normal as the sum of Gaussian random variables, the nonlinearity of the activation function ϕ\phiϕ means that x1(x)x^1(x)x1(x) is not normal, and so we do not necessarily have a Gaussian process prior. In the next post, I will describe the results by Neal (1994) and J. Lee et al. (2018), which shows that in the infinite width limit, neural networks of any fixed depth are Gaussian processes!
entry.summary: In the last part, we went over an introduction to the Bayesian approach in machine learning, where we think of a neural network model from a weight-space point of view. In this post, I will go over an alternative approach, whereby we apply Bayesian inference directly in the function space. That is, instead of thinking of the model as specifying the probability distribution over the weights in a neural network, we are thinking of it as specifying a probability distribution over functions whose domain is the space of inputs of the network, and the codomain as the space of its outputs.

entry.title: A Bayesian View of Neural Networks

link.title: A Bayesian View of Neural Networks

entry.content:
There have been numerous recent papers by J.Lee et. al. (Google Brain), Matthews et. al. (Cambridge), etc. studying the behavior of wide deep neural networks in the infinite width limit. In that regime, these neural networks can be thought of as Gaussian processes, which allows for a Bayesian treatment. In this first post, I will provide a gentle introduction in this subject.

Bayes’ rule

We start with the well-loved Bayes rule: P(H∣E)=P(E∣H)P(H)P(E). P(H|E) = \frac{P(E|H)P(H)}{P(E)}.P(H∣E)=P(E)P(E∣H)P(H)​. To understand this rule:

  1. HHH stands for hypothesis and EEE for evidence.
  2. P(H∣E) P(H \mid E) P(H∣E) is the posterior probability, which is the probability of HHH given that we have observed EEE
  3. As opposed to that, the prior P(H)P(H)P(H) is the prior, i.e. the probability of HHH when we have no information on EEE.
  4. P(E∣H) P(E \mid H) P(E∣H) is the likelihood of observing EEE when we are under hypothesis HHH, and
  5. P(E)P(E)P(E) is the marginal probability of evidence EEE happens regardless of hypothesis. What Bayes rule gives us is a way to update our belief on the probability distribution of the hypotheses as we gather more evidence/information.

Bayesian learning of weights

In the context of machine learning, we can think of the hypotheses as the weights w\bold ww in the neural network, and the evidence as the training data D\bold DD. In the step of initialization, we often let the weights w\bold ww to be randomly generated, usually from a Gaussian with sufficiently large variance. In the Bayesian treatment, we can think of this as our prior belief on the weights: w∼N(0,Σ) \bold w \sim \mathcal N(0, \bold \Sigma) w∼N(0,Σ). Then, using Bayes rule, for a model of neural network, we can obtain the posterior probability of the weights given that we have seen training data, i.e. we updated our belief as a consequence of having observed the data.

Example: Single Layer Network for Binary Classification

In this example, we have inputs x∈Rd \bold x \in \mathbb R^d x∈Rd and outputs y∈[0,1] y \in [0,1] y∈[0,1], where yyy is interpreted as the probability that x\bold x x belongs to class 1. The simple architecture is as follows:

As such, we have f(x,w)=σ(wTx)=11+exp⁡(−wTx). f(\bold x, \bold w) = \sigma(\bold w^T \bold x) = \frac{1}{1 + \exp(-\bold w^T \bold x)}. f(x,w)=σ(wTx)=1+exp(−wTx)1​. Thus, given the current weight, the predictive distribution for the output of the neural network is First, we compute the likelihood of the data D={(x(i),y(i)):1≤i≤n} \bold D = \{(\bold x^{(i)}, y^{(i)}): 1 \leq i \leq n\} D={(x(i),y(i)):1≤i≤n}: p(D∣w)=∏i=1np(y(i)∣x(i),w)=∏i=1nσ(wTx(i))y(i)(1−σ(wTx(i)))1−y(i). p(D \mid \bold w) = \prod_{i=1}^n p( y^{(i)} \mid x^{(i)}, w ) = \prod_{i=1}^n \sigma(\bold w^T \bold x^{(i)})^{y^{(i)}} (1- \sigma(\bold w^T \bold x^{(i)}))^{1-y^{(i)}}. p(D∣w)=i=1∏n​p(y(i)∣x(i),w)=i=1∏n​σ(wTx(i))y(i)(1−σ(wTx(i)))1−y(i).

Now, we can use Bayes rule to compute the posterior p(w∣D)=p(D∣w)p(w)p(D)=∏i=1nσ(wTx(i))y(i)(1−σ(wTx(i)))1−y(i)exp⁡(−∥w∥2/2)∫Rd∏i=1nσ(w′Tx(i))y(i)(1−σ(w′Tx(i)))1−y(i)exp⁡(−∥w′∥2/2)dw′. p(\bold w \mid D) = \frac{p(D\mid \bold w)p(\bold w)}{p(\bold D)} = \frac{\prod_{i=1}^n \sigma(\bold w^T \bold x^{(i)})^{y^{(i)}} (1- \sigma(\bold w^T \bold x^{(i)}))^{1-y^{(i)}} \exp(-\| \bold w \|^2/2) }{ \int_{\R^d} \prod_{i=1}^n \sigma(\bold w'^T \bold x^{(i)})^{y^{(i)}} (1- \sigma(\bold w'^T \bold x^{(i)}))^{1-y^{(i)}} \exp(-\| \bold w' \|^2/2) d\bold w'.} p(w∣D)=p(D)p(D∣w)p(w)​=∫Rd​∏i=1n​σ(w′Tx(i))y(i)(1−σ(w′Tx(i)))1−y(i)exp(−∥w′∥2/2)dw′.∏i=1n​σ(wTx(i))y(i)(1−σ(wTx(i)))1−y(i)exp(−∥w∥2/2)​ Note that the denominator is simply a normalization constant to make the posterior a probability distribution.

This looks complicated, but let’s see a little example, where x∈R2x \in \R^2 x∈R2 and y=0y = 0 y=0 if 0.5x1+0.5x2>00.5 x_1 + 0.5 x_2 > 0 0.5x1​+0.5x2​>0, and 111 otherwise.

Here is the plot of the Gaussian prior over w∼N(0,I2)\bold w \sim \mathcal N(0, I_2) w∼N(0,I2​):

We used the following set of 4 data points:

After numerically computing the posterior, we get the following distribution:

Note that the posterior distribution is more concentrated around the true value (0.5,0.5)(0.5,0.5)(0.5,0.5).

Comparison with MLE

In the usual approach, we use gradient descent to find

wMLE∗=arg⁡max⁡wP(D∣w),\mathbf{w^*_{MLE}}= \arg\max_{\mathbf{w}} P(D \mid \mathbf{w}),wMLE∗​=argwmax​P(D∣w),

which amounts to find a single parameter that best fits our data given the current model. On the other hand, the Bayesian approach tries to understand the distribution of parameters given the model and the training data. As a result, we can also understand the predictive distribution of the model: p(f(x)∣D,w)=∫f(x,w)P(w∣D)dw p(f(\bold x) \mid D, \bold w) = \int f(\bold x, \bold w) P(\bold w \mid D) d\bold w p(f(x)∣D,w)=∫f(x,w)P(w∣D)dw This means that we can also compute the confidence in the model output.

Another estimator that arises naturally from the Bayesian approach is the maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimator: wMAP∗=arg⁡max⁡wP(D∣w)P(w), \mathbf{w^*_{MAP}} = \arg\max_{\mathbf{w}} P(D \mid \mathbf{w} ) P(\mathbf{w}),wMAP∗​=argwmax​P(D∣w)P(w), which is the mode of the posterior distribution. In the case where we have a compact parameter space and a uniform prior distribution, it is clear that wMAP∗=wMLE∗\mathbf{w^*_{MAP}} = \mathbf{w^*_{MLE}}wMAP∗​=wMLE∗​. Thus, one can view the MLE as a special case of the MAP estimator. Notice that when we use a Gaussian prior with mean 000, the MAP estimator has smaller norm than the MLE. This is because large norm is punished by P(w)∝exp⁡(−12wTΣ−1w).P(\bold w) \propto \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2} \bold w^T \Sigma^{-1} \bold w \right).P(w)∝exp(−21​wTΣ−1w). In the case where the data is also normally distributed with respect to the weights w\bold ww, using the MAP estimator amounts to a well-known form of regularization called ridge-regression.

In this part, we have explored a very simple Bayesian treatment of neural networks, where we think of the random weight initialization as giving a prior on the weights. In the next part, I will explain how infinite-width neural networks will correspond to Gaussian process priors over functions.
entry.summary: There have been numerous recent papers by J.Lee et. al. (Google Brain), Matthews et. al. (Cambridge), etc. studying the behavior of wide deep neural networks in the infinite width limit. In that regime, these neural networks can be thought of as Gaussian processes, which allows for a Bayesian treatment. In this first post, I will provide a gentle introduction in this subject.
